subject: mathematics
explanation: Direct proportion: as one quantity increases, the other increases at the same rate (y = kx). Inverse proportion: as one quantity increases, the other decreases (y = k/x). Examples: Direct - more workers, more work done. Inverse - more speed, less time taken. Look for constant ratios (direct) or constant products (inverse).

questionFormations.description: Proportion questions test understanding of relationships between quantities and scaling:

examples: 4 books cost £12, how much do 7 books cost?
Car travels 150 miles in 3 hours, distance in 5 hours?
types.strategy: Find unit rate: cost per book, speed per hour. Then multiply by new quantity

examples: 8 workers complete job in 6 days, time for 12 workers?
At 60mph journey takes 4 hours, time at 80mph?
types.strategy: Find constant product: workers × time, speed × time. Divide by new value

examples: More fuel used, further distance traveled
More people sharing pizza, smaller slice each
types.strategy: Direct: both increase/decrease together. Inverse: one up, other down
Direct proportion: straight line through (0,0). Inverse: curved hyperbola

examples: If y is directly proportional to x, and y=20 when x=4...
y varies inversely with x, y=12 when x=3, find y when x=9
types.strategy: Direct: find k in y=kx. Inverse: find k in y=k/x

examples: Cost proportional to weight, time inversely proportional to workers
Distinguish between different types in same context
types.strategy: Identify each relationship separately, apply appropriate method

examTips: Direct proportion: ratio stays constant (y₁/x₁ = y₂/x₂)
Inverse proportion: product stays constant (x₁ × y₁ = x₂ × y₂)
Check if both quantities increase together (direct) or oppositely (inverse)
Units help: same units suggest direct, different units often inverse

examples.question: If 4 apples cost £2, how much do 10 apples cost? (Direct proportion)
examples.explanation: Direct proportion: cost ÷ apples is constant. £2 ÷ 4 = £0.50 per apple. So 10 apples = 10 × £0.50 = £5

examples.question: If 6 workers take 8 days to complete a job, how long will 12 workers take? (Inverse proportion)
examples.explanation: Inverse proportion: workers × days is constant. 6 × 8 = 48. So 12 workers take 48 ÷ 12 = 4 days
